0.cdata!: Bolivia - Proyecto de la Carretera Abapó-Camiri

abstracts.cdata!:
The Bolivia Abapo-Camiri Highway Project
            had a satisfactory outcome, is likely to be sustainable, and
            had a modest development impact. Bank and Borrower
            performances were satisfactory. Lessons cited included the
            following: 1) A sound institutional framework with adequate
            procurement mechanisms that ensure the selection of good
            contractors and consultants is able to overcome an adverse
            environment and is conducive to obtain reasonable costs for
            high quality outputs. 2) Substantial social impacts and a
            more inclusive development approach can be achieved by
            incorporating strategic elements targeting access for the
            poor. 3) A resourceful project design is fundamental to
            manage conflicting issues turning them into positive
            outcomes. Well-conceived and implemented Resettlement Action
            Plan (RAP), Community Relations Program (CRP), and
            Indigenous Peoples Development Plan (IPDP) are effective
            means for enhancing community participation and ensuring
            that the project's interventions reach the most
            vulnerable. 4) Contracting out the implementation of the
            IPDP and CRP to independent and specialized consulting
            firms, as opposed to including them as an additional item in
            the civil works contract, is a good practice. 5) Introducing
            new maintenance contract schemes requires a gradual
            implementation approach according to the level of maturity
            of the road sector, based on an assessment of the
            willingness and flexibility to adjust to a new setting. 6)
            Strong and continued political support is fundamental to
            ensure substantial and sustained institutional development
            in the road sector.

abstracts.cdata!:
The Abapo-Camiri Highway Project aims to
            improve transport conditions along a strategic north-south
            corridor linking the Bolivian departments of Beni, Santa,
            Cruz, Chuquisaca, and Tarija and continuing to Argentina and
            Paraguay. By rehabilitating and improving the Abapo-Camiri
            Highway, the project seeks to lower transport costs, foster
            the economic development of the project area, improve the
            income level of the indigenous peoples in the area, and
            establish economic transport links between the
            Borrower's territories and neighboring countries. There
            are four project components. 1) Abapo-Camiri Highway
            component will finance 80 percent of the civil works and
            supervision of the reconstruction and paving of the highway.
            2) Access road to El Espino component will finance 80
            percent of the civil works and supervision of the
            reconstruction and paving of an existing dirt road that runs
            parallel to the rail track to Charagua. 3) Comprehensive
            maintenance by contract will finance 20 percent of the civil
            works and 80 percent of the supervision of a comprehensive
            maintenance program covering about 900 km of the basic
            highway network of the Departamento de Santa Cruz. 4)
            Institutional strengthening will provide technical
            assistance for consulting services, procurement, and
            implementation of resettlement plan.

repnme.cdata!:
Bolivia - Abapo-Camiri Highway Project
            (formerly Camiri Road Project) : environmental impact assessment

abstracts.cdata!:
This is an environmental assessment of
            the Abapo-Camiri Highway Project (formerly the Camiri Road
            Project), which reconstructs and improves transport
            conditions along a north-south corridor connecting Bolivian
            departments and continuing to Argentina and Paraguay. Some
            negative environmental impacts and their mitigations include
            the following: During construction, decibel levels will be
            reduced in the population centers most sensitive to noise;
            the hours of operation restricted; greenbelts erected; and
            car velocity and horn-blowing limited. To reduce dust and
            emissions caused by vehicles and machinery, the roads will
            be sprayed, oil and other pollutants will not be burned, and
            insulation will be hung in dwellings. Equipment and
            machinery will be operated to comply with air quality and
            noise level standards, including covering transport trucks.
            Solid waste disposal and basic sanitation measures will
            prevent soil contamination. To prevent landslides resulting
            from deforestation and vegetation removal, barricades will
            be erected. Mulching, bundling wood and revegetation will
            avoid erosion and minimize sedimentation. A drainage system
            and protection works will shore up embankments. Compacted
            topsoil will have its natural permeability restored.
            Drainage systems will be dug along river banks only after
            hydraulic analysis. Only minimal quantities of explosives
            will be used at quarries. To protect area fauna, hunting and
            fishing will be prohibited.
